entry.dc:title: The efficiency of tesseral arithmetic for 2.5D image manipulation on serial computers and transputer arrays.
entry.dc:creator: Jackson M.
entry.prism:publicationName: Spatial data processing using tesseral methods. Collected papers from TW1 and TW2
entry.dc:description: An investigation of the applicability of tesseral arithmetic and tesseral addressing to a 2.5D vision system is described. In particular a comparison is made of image manipulation speeds using tesseral addition and multiplication with quaternion and Cartesian methods. The approach is largely theoretical but also describes practical simulations on a VAX computer. The extension of the algorithms to a Transputer array is briefly discussed. -from Authors

entry.dc:title: The Constraints on Images of Rectangular Polyhedra
entry.dc:creator: Kanatani K.
entry.prism:publicationName: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
entry.dc:description: This paper discusses how polyhedron interpretation techniques are simplified if the objects are rectangular trihedral polyhedra. This restriction enables one to compute the spatial orientation of a given corner and its motion from its image in terms of polar coordinates, Eulerian angles, and quaternions. One can also interpret the shape and the face adjacency from local information only. The necessary constraints are listed, and some examples are given to compare the presented scheme to existing ones. The possible nonuniqueness of the interpretation is also discussed. Â© 1986 IEEE
entry.authkeywords: Computer vision | constraint | Eulerian angle | machine intelligence | quaternion | rectangular polyhedron | shape analysis | spatial orientation

entry.dc:title: KINEMATICS AND STRUCTURE OF A RIGID OBJECT FROM A SEQUENCE OF NOISY IMAGES.
entry.dc:creator: Broida T.J.
entry.dc:description: The problem considered involves the use of a sequence of images of a moving object to estimate its structure and kinematics. The object is assumed to be rigid, and its motion is assumed to be 'smooth'. Motion is modeled by retaining an arbitrary number of terms in the appropriate Taylor series expansions. Translational motion involves a standard rectilinear model, while rotational motion is described with quaternions. Neglected terms of the Taylor series are modeled as process noise in the recursive formulation. Observation of object features involves object structure parameters. A state-space model is constructed, incorporating both kinematic and structural states, and is appropriate for solution by either recursive or batch techniques. A set of object match points is assumed to be available, consisting of fixed features on the object, the image plane coordinates of which have been extracted from successive images in the sequence. The measured data are the noisy image plane coordinates of this set (or of a subset of this set) of object match points, taken from each image in the sequence. High noise levels (up to 20% of the object image size) are allowed. The problem is formulated as a parameter estimation and tracking problem, which can use an arbitrarily large number of images in a sequence.
